title: Andaleeb Rahman
text:
I am an applied economist at the Tata-Cornell Institute for Agriculture and Nutrition (TCI), Cornell University, Ithaca, NY. My research lies broadly in the area of developmental impact evaluation with a focus on food security, nutrition, agriculture, social protection, and political economy.
Contact: Google Scholar | LinkedIn | Email: ar687@cornell.edu

title: Andaleeb Rahman
text:
Focus, Form, and Scope
Read the book (Open Access) →
Social protection programs, also referred to as safety nets, have emerged as one of the most important social policy instruments to alleviate poverty and livelihood risks in the global developmental discourse. According to a 2015 World Bank report, around 2.5 billion people globally are covered by safety nets, through which 36 percent of the very poor have managed to escape extreme poverty.
Key Questions:

How can safety nets be designed which serve both vast rural populations and the rising urban poor?
How can we ensure these schemes are not subjected to errors of targeting when catering to large and diverse populations?
Are these schemes a palliative cure or a tool for furthering India towards long-term resilient development?
How does politics influence the idea of welfare in India?
Is there sufficient state capacity to bring about improved governance and institutional reforms?

Our Approach:
We study the success and failures of India’s social safety net system in terms of three aspects: scope, form, and focus. By scope, we mean the objectives of safety net programs; focus refers to the beneficiaries; and form refers to the modality or design. After deliberating upon the achievements and limitations of various welfare programs, this book looks ahead and highlights key challenges and scope for innovations in designing a future social safety net system for a rising India.

title: Andaleeb Rahman
text:
Read the book (Open Access) →
Over the last decade, increases in per capita incomes, greater urbanization rates, increase in literacy rates, population growth and poverty reduction has characterized this high growth process. Yet, in a small farm dominant country like India, poor infrastructure and a lack of institutional support has excluded many small holders from benefiting from the growth process. At the macro level, the growth process has been highly inequitable benefiting some states more than others. At the consumer end, increases in income and income generating opportunities continue to coexist with poor health outcomes.
Key Questions:

How can India move towards the SDGs – zero malnutrition and poverty?
What are the ways to re-organize the production systems to feed a nutritious diet for the growing population, while ensuring sustainable agriculture systems?
Can we come up with newer ways to ensure that economic growth stimulates the rural economy through providing more livelihood opportunities?
Are there ways to ensure greater equity in regional growth across the country while still guiding the Indian economy towards greater structural transformation?
